column1: Ciechanów [t͡ɕeˈxanuf] (listen) (German: Zichenau) is a town in north-central Poland. As of 2018
column4: it was the capital of the Ciechanów Voivodeship. Since 1999
column5: it has been situated in the Masovian Voivodeship.

column1: The settlement is first mentioned in a 1065 document by Bolesław II the Bold handing the land over to the church. The medieval gord in Ciechanów numbered approximately 3
column3: and together with the province of Mazovia
column4: it probably became part of the Polish state in the late 10th century.

column2: Ciechanów is mentioned as the seat of a castellany (Rethiborius Castellanus de Techanow (Racibor
column3: Kasztelan Ciechanowa)). In 1400 Janusz I of Czersk granted Ciechanów town privileges. The area eventually become a separate duchy with Casimir I of Warsaw using the title "dominus et heres lub dominus et princeps Ciechanoviensis." In the Middle Ages
column4: the defensive gord of Ciechanów protected northern Mazovia from raids of Lithuanians
column7: the Teutonic Knights. It is not known when it was granted a town charter. This must have happened before 1475
column8: as a document from that year
column9: issued by Duke Janusz II of Warsaw
column10: states that Ciechanów has a Chełmno town charter.

column1: The town was handed over to Bona Sforza
column2: as her dowry. Ciechanów prospered until the Swedish invasion of Poland (1655-1660)

column1: After the second partition of Poland (1793)
column2: Ciechanów briefly became seat of a newly created voivodeship. In 1795
column3: it was annexed by the Kingdom of Prussia
column4: and reduced to the status of a provincial town in Przasnysz county. In 1806
column6: Ciechanów was ransacked and destroyed. In 1807 it became part of the short-lived Polish Duchy of Warsaw. Since 1815
column7: the town belonged to Russian-controlled Congress Poland. Its residents actively supported Polish rebellions. In the late 19th century
column8: Ciechanów emerged as a local trade and industry center. In 1864
column10: in 1867 it became seat of a county
column11: in 1877 a rail station of the Vistula River Railroad was completed
column12: and in 1882 a sugar refinery was opened. The period of prosperity was short

column5: and the town was a military garrison

column1: Ciechanów was captured by the Wehrmacht on the night of September 3/4
column2: 1939. The town was annexed by Nazi Germany and was known as Zichenau in German. It was the capital of Regierungsbezirk Zichenau
column3: a new subdivision of the Province of East Prussia. The vast majority of the Polish and Jewish population was seen as racially inferior and Germany planned its eventual annihilation. The Einsatzgruppe V entered the city on September 10
column5: and carried out first mass arrests among local Polish intelligentsia. Residents were imprisoned in Gestapo jails established in municipal buildings and the city hall. The Germans carried out mass searches of Polish and Jewish homes
column8: which were desecrated and looted. Several hundred Poles were transported from the jail in Ciechanów and murdered in large massacres in the nearby village of Ościsłowo as part of Intelligenzaktion. Also local disabled people were murdered in Ościsłowo
column10: 1940. Local teachers were arrested in October and November 1939
column11: and deported to the Soldau concentration camp
column12: where they were murdered in December 1939
column13: and some were also murdered in the Mauthausen concentration camp.Poles were also subjected to expulsions. Around 600 people were expelled in December 1939
column14: further expulsions were carried out in subsequent years. In Ciechanów
column15: the Germans also organized a transit camp for Poles deported for forced labor to the areas of Klaipeda
column16: Tilsit (Sovetsk) and Königsberg (Kaliningrad).Before World War II
column17: Ciechanów was home to a large Jewish community of 1
column19: but during the Nazi German occupation
column21: the majority of the Jewish community were transported to the Red Forest (Czerwony Bór) northeast of town and murdered in a mass shooting. During the war many Polish Jews and resistance fighters were executed by the Germans in the castle.

column3: Ciechanów was captured from Nazi Germany by the Red Army
column4: and was restored to Poland after the war.
